statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: North Carolina State 74, Savannah State 53
article.story: RALEIGH, N.C. (AP) -- Gavin Grant scored 19 points and Brandon Costner added 18, helping sluggish North Carolina State beat Savannah State 74-53 Saturday at Reynolds Coliseum. Ben McCauley finished with 15 points for the Wolfpack (6-2), who play seven of their next eight games at home. N.C. State led by only four points at halftime, and the margin still was six midway through the second half before the Tigers (5-7) finally went away. Grant and Courtney Fells highlighted the final minutes with emphatic dunks, with Grant doing a reverse, two-hander and Fells adding a tomahawk jam in traffic. McCauley then added his own punctuation mark, taking a lob pass from Grant and slamming it home as he was fouled. Until the late theatrics, the biggest cheers from the less-than-capacity crowd had come for new N.C. State football coach Tom O'Brien, who was introduced early in the first half. He saluted the home fans by holding each hand high to form the mock Wolfpack call that's a familiar sight for the red-clad faithful. At halftime, dozens of students came courtside to meet their new coach, and O'Brien patiently shook every hand, signed autographs and posed for pictures. He even hugged one zealous student, drawing laughs and more applause. Perhaps those in attendance were anxious for any reason to get excited. N.C. State struggled to put away the overmatched Tigers, trailing 9-0 barely 5 minutes into the game and needing another iron man-like performance from its starters to snap a two-game losing streak. A game after four played the entire 40 minutes in a loss at West Virginia, each of them went deep into the second half without much rest. Grant and Bryan Nieman both again went without a break. Finally, the home team came alive to keep N.C. State undefeated in what has been dubbed the Heritage Game, an annual return to venerable Reynolds Coliseum. The "Big Barn" was the site of nearly 800 games for the Wolfpack while also hosting 13 Atlantic Coast Conference tournaments and eight NCAA regionals. The final margin was the closest of the give games, thanks to a spirited effort from the Tigers. They came in without a victory since Nov. 19, and their losing streak reached seven games. Savannah State fell to 8-102 against Division I opponents since moving up in 2002. Javon Randolph had 19 points for the Tigers, who travel to Iowa State, West Virginia and Louisville before returning home later in the month.
